text: Almost half (49%) of the pesticide products registered in Kenya are toxic or very toxic to marine life. Europe is the market leader in terms of agrochemicals sales in the region. name: Boniface Mwangi
text: Consumers and farmers are ignorant about the extent of agrochemicals use, their concentrations in food and environment and their possible effects on the environment and ecosystem services. #FoodSafetyNowpic.twitter.com/sb1GkwuH6m

name: Boniface Mwangi
text: Despite European restrictions and interventions to use less hazardous products, some of the banned  agrochemicals are still in use in Kenya, and continue to threaten the environment and the health of  citizens.Non-communicable diseases include diabetes, Alzheimer‚Äôs, cancer, etcpic.twitter.com/BYVCEt4NpH

name: Boniface Mwangi
text: Due to the high toxicity towards human health and the environment many of the pesticides Kenya is importing are banned or heavily restricted in Europe. The pesticides imported in Kenya contain hazardous products. #FoodSafetyNowpic.twitter.com/avwNGPtWlk

name: Boniface Mwangi
text: Most of the farming systems in Kenya are small-scale farming systems with a maximum size of 2 acres, which are very often situated along hill-slopes and close to water ways and therefore prone to the risk of runoff of soil with pesticides attached to it. #FoodSafetyNowpic.twitter.com/wbRsZUoCpz

name: Boniface Mwangi
text: In 2018 Kenya imported 17,803 tonnes of pesticides valued at 128 million dollars. The agriculture sector employs more than 40% of the total population and more than 70% of Kenya‚Äôs rural people, that means they come in contact highly hazardous pesticides. #FoodSafetyNowpic.twitter.com/c4IwmXYVl5

name: Pope Boniface X
text: As Noah was the governor of his time, so We are the governor of Our time, receiving full jurisdiction from Our Lord to govern the affairs of the end of days and the end of the Holy Sacrifice.

name: Pope Boniface X
text: Like the days of Noah, We call all the nations into the Ark (the Church) under Our governance.  There is no salvation outside of it.  If they do not heed OUR WARNING SOON, THEY WILL BE DESTROYED.

name: Pope Boniface X
text: Does the fact that Japheth received the greatest blessings and thus the most conversions to the truth exclude other nations?  No, ALL NATIONS are called into the Church.

name: Pope Boniface X
text: Japheth (Europeans) received the greatest and richest blessings from Almighty God.  He was the son who dwelt in the tents, conquering all, and did not even have to build them.  Shem had to labor to build the tents (create the scriptures), and Ham received no blessing.

name: Pope Boniface X
text: We see that the sons of Japheth (Europe), soon to become the glorious Roman Empire upon its conversion, because it would be the Empire that would embrace the Faith, went north and also west from Mount Ararat, Turkey.  Japheth was given the greatest blessing by Noah.pic.twitter.com/Ts30wNaGs1

name: Katrin Boniface
text: "its not the bit its the hands" is a bit of an exaggeration (and sometimes justification), but the hands must be accounted for in the equation just as much as the horse's training, conformation, mood, and preference.

name: Katrin Boniface
text: I prefer to ride with a bit of contact. Which means high ports, long shanks, and especially bits or bridles that slide around are generally not good fits for me. I can adapt, if its what the horse uses, but my preference and best riding is elsewhere.

name: Katrin Boniface
text:
And there are tons of other options. Including the aforesaid bike chain hack. It's bitless, but far far far from pressure-less.
I once started a horse under saddle in one. That was a wild week. Not the recommended tool.https://www.smartpakequine.com/pt/weaver-pony-hackamore-with-gum-rubber-covered-bike-chain-noseband--19273¬†‚Ä¶

name: Katrin Boniface
text:
I've use a ton of short shank fleece hacks. They're great for camp. And I've had no problem doing lateral work on two reins and keeping the horse light.
I bought a fancy one and its terrible. It pushes the cheekpiece into the eye.

name: Katrin Boniface
text:
I usually don't like riding in rope halters. Or rather, I don't like training in them, they're vague. I know plenty of folks who do. Including some who take greenies on 30 mile rides and never touch the thing. They come back "broke."
But I ride Buffy in hers. We barely need it.

name: Katrin Boniface
text: Sidepulls are great. I'd have one for Leo, if the weren't $80+ for what is basicaly a stabilized halter. A lot of work goes into good bridlemaking, they deserve it. But we aren't showing. The halter is fine. Its even adjustable, so it doesn't slide much.

name: Katrin Boniface
text: Lots of horses and riders do well in bosals. I find them clumsy. I get a softer response from a plain noseband, and I have other ways of introducing curb pressure. But for a lot of teams, they're a good option.

name: Katrin Boniface
text: There are a few modified "knock off" Cooks that I might consider if I ended up with one (though none I've felt worth the $$$).

name: Katrin Boniface
text:
I will never buy a Cooks. I've only ever used them at owners' request, and those where enough to convince me they had no place in my tool box. 
I'd honestly rather use a bike chain hack.

name: Katrin Boniface
text: Sometimes bridless (neck rope for safety, and clarity if needed) just to test out how the rest of our communication is doing.
